title: If I want to transfer to a UK university from a community college, do I have to have the required ACT? I have a high GPA from high school and community college but will I be overlooked due to the ACT score? - Quora

response.answer_text: If you complete community college and come out with an associate degree, you can use that as an entrance qualification to many UK universities. I've not seen any reading they will take students who have gone to CC but not completed their associate degree. If the university you're interested in doesn't mention associate degrees on their website you should contact them and ask (there is normally an “if your qualification is not shown context us” link). Durham, Bristol and Southampton are among those that have associate degrees on their website and give the following equivalence (without A*A*A for Southampton) between associate degree GPAs and A level grades for undergraduate entry, so this seems fairly well established (Durham: Country Information; Bristol: USA; Southampton: Information for students from the USA): Associates Degree A*A*A – Associates Degree with a GPA of 3.4 or better. A*AA – Associates Degree with a GPA of 3.3 or better. AAA – Associates Degree with a GPA of 3.2 or better. AAB – Associates Degree with a GPA of 3.1 or better. ABB – Associates Degree with a GPA of 3.0 or better. Other universities: Edinburgh states a minimum GPA of 3.0 for entry with an associate degree (USA). Kent wants a GPA of 3.2 (Information for students from the USA - University of Kent). Cardiff says “successful completion of an associate degree” (Entry requirements for the United States).

If you have completed your associates degree from your community college, then follow Robert Minchin’s excellent answer. If you have not completed your associates degree, then what you have to present is your secondary school qualifications. You cannot successfully apply to any university, in any country without meeting the requirements. So the short answer is, if you want the community college to count, you have to finish your associates degree (or be in the process of finishing your last year), at which point your ACT score is irrelevant. If you haven’t finished your associates degree, then your ACT is still relevant.
